facts.text: Appellant instituted the suit on the 15th of March, 1944 in forma pauperis

anchor.surface_text: On the 15th of March, 1944 the appellant instituted the suit out of which this appeal arises in forma pauperis on the allegation that he was the adopted son of Krishtarao

facts.text: Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving him surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai and a son Dattatraya

anchor.surface_text: Gurunath, the plaintiff, claims that he was adopted in 1943 by Gangabai, widow of Krishtarao. Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving him surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai and a son Dattatraya.

facts.text: Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving him surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath

anchor.surface_text: Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving him surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath. Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya while Jagannath died in the year 1914.

facts.text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya

anchor.surface_text: Sundarabai died shortly after Dattatraya while Jagannath died in the year 1914. After an interval of about 30 years since his death,

facts.text: Jagannath died in the year 1914

anchor.surface_text: while Jagannath died in the year 1914. After an interval of about 30 years since his death, it is alleged that Gangabai who survived both her son,

facts.text: Gangabai adopted the plaintiff Gurunath in 1943

anchor.surface_text: Gurunath, the plaintiff, claims that he was adopted in 1943 by Gangabai, widow of Krishtarao. Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving him surviving two widows Radhabai and Gangabai

facts.text: Defendants disputed the plaintiffs adoption on the ground that Gangabais power to adopt was extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913

anchor.surface_text: The defendants who are the sons and grandsons of the first cousin of Krishtarao disputed the plaintiffs adoption on the ground that Gangabais power to adopt was extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913,

facts.text: Gangabai in her written statement supported the plaintiffs claim and asserted that the senior widow Radhabai had given consent to her adopting the plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: leaving behind him a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath who could continue the family line. Gangabai in her written statement supported the plaintiffs claim and asserted that the senior widow Radhabai had given consent

facts.text: The trial judge upheld the defendants contention and dismissed the plaintiffs suit

anchor.surface_text: to the adoption. The trial judge upheld the defendants contention and dismissed the plaintiffs suit. The factum of the plaintiffs adoption was however upheld,

facts.text: The factum of the plaintiffs adoption was upheld by the trial judge

anchor.surface_text: The factum of the plaintiffs adoption was however upheld, and it was further held that Radhabai did not give her consent to the adoption.

facts.text: Trial judge held that Radhabai did not give her consent to the adoption

anchor.surface_text: and it was further held that Radhabai did not give her consent to the adoption. On appeal this decision was affirmed by the High Court

facts.text: High Court affirmed the trial court decision and held that Gangabais power to adopt came to an end when her son died leaving a son and a widow

anchor.surface_text: On appeal this decision was affirmed by the High Court and it was held that Gangabais power to adopt came to an end at the time when her son died leaving a son and a widow to continue the family line.

facts.text: High Court gave no finding on whether Radhabai had given her consent to the adoption

anchor.surface_text: No finding was given on the question whether Radhabai had given her consent to the adoption. That perhaps would have been the simplest way to end the dispute.

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed entitlement to possession of Krishtarao's properties and declaration regarding compensation money for land acquired by Hubli Municipality

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that he was the adopted son of Krishtarao and adopted to him by Gangabai, his junior widow, and as such was entitled to the possession of his adoptive fathers properties comprised in the suit.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on December 10, 1954 by MEHR CHAND MAHAJAN C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. December 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MEHR CHAND MAHAJAN C. J.-This appeal raises a question of importance whether a widow

Appeal by Special Leave granted by this Courts Order dated the 24th September, 1951 from the Judgment and Decree dated the 2nd day of September, 1949 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay in Appeal No. 274 of 1948

This appeal raises a question of importance whether a widow can exercise a power of adoption conferred on her or possessed by her at any time during her life irrespective of any devolution of property or changes in the family or other circumstances and even after a grandson has come on the scene but has subsequently died without leaving a widow or a son.

concepts.interpretation: Widow can exercise power during lifetime but subject to limitations where duty to continue line passes to son, grandson or son's widow competent to continue it.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: n being held valid for all other purposes, which is the view that the lower Courts have taken of the judgment,

concepts.unlisted_description: Authority of Hindu widow to adopt a son to continue husband's line under Hindu law

anchor.surface_text: Against the decision of the High Court this appeal in forma pauperis is now before us by special leave. The only question canvassed in the appeal is in respect to the validity of the plaintiffs adoption. It was contended that Hindu Shastric Law itself sets no limit to the exercise of the widows power of adoption

concepts.interpretation: Sets no absolute limit to widow's power but courts impose limits based on equity.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: arising out of the adoption made by Shrimati Chundrabullee and decided in 1876 and 1878. The judgment in the first of these cases, i.e. in Bhoobun Mo

concepts.unlisted_description: Ancient Hindu textual law on adoption without explicit time limits on widow's power

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we are unable to depart from the rule that a widows power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to continue the line by adoption.

concepts.interpretation: Power extinguishes once son passes duty to grandson or son's widow; cannot revive even if they die without issue.

anchor.surface_text: In their Lordships opinion, it is clear that the foundation of the Brahminical doctrine of adoption is the duty which every Hindu owes to his ancestors to provide for the continuance of the line and the solemnization of the necessary rites.

concepts.interpretation: Primary purpose is spiritual continuance of line, property devolution secondary; determines validity over temporal considerations.

arguments.claim: Hindu Shastric Law itself sets no limit to the exercise of the widow's power of adoption once acquired, exercisable during lifetime when necessity arises to continue husband's line

anchor.surface_text: The only question canvassed in the appeal is in respect to the validity of the plaintiffs adoption. It was contended that Hindu Shastric Law itself sets no limit to the exercise of the widows power of adoption once she has acquired that power or is possessed of it, and that being so, the power can be exercised by her during her life-time when necessity arises for the exercise of it for the purpose of continuing the line of her husband.

arguments.claim: Though Shastric law sets no limit, judicially the power is not unlimited and ends when another heir comes on scene and passes duty of continuing the line

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it was argued that though Hindu Shastric Law itself sets no limit to the exercise of the power, yet it has long been judicially recognised that the power is not an unlimited and absolute one, and that it comes to an end when another heir has come on the scene and he has passed on to another the duty of continuing the line.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant placed considerable reliance on two decisions of the Indian High Courts... Reference in this connection was made to the decision of the Nagpur High Court in Bapuji v. Gangaram. There a Hindu died leaving a widow and his son and the son died leaving a widow only who re-married. It was held that the power of the mother revived on the re-marriage of the sons widow.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we are unable to depart from the rule that a widows power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to continue the line by adoption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation based on consistent Privy Council and High Court precedents over three quarters of a century, integrated into Hindu law despite no clear Shastric text

holdings.text: the rule that the power of a widow to adopt comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to adopt has become a part of Hindu Law

anchor.surface_text: The result of these series of decisions is, that now for about three quarters of a century the rule that the power of a widow to adopt comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the sons widow competent to adopt has become a part of Hindu Law. though the reasons for limiting the power may not be traceable to any Shastric text

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long line of authoritative decisions establishes rule as integral to Hindu law, reasons evolve but upheld

holdings.text: in the absence of any clear Shastric text the courts have authority to decide cases on principles of justice, equity and good conscience and it is not possible to hold that the reasons stated in support of the rule are not consistent with these principles

anchor.surface_text: It is well known that in the absence of any clear Shastric text the courts have authority to decide cases on principles of justice, equity and good conscience and it is not possible to hold that the reasons stated in support of the rule are not consistent with these principles.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial authority to interpret uncodified law supports the limitation rule as equitable

holdings.text: This argument, in our opinion, is not well founded as it is based on an incorrect apprehension of the true basis of the rule... the power of Gangabai to make the adoption revived and thus the adoption was valid

anchor.surface_text: it should be held that when the son and his widow were dead and the grandson to whom he handed the torch for continuing the line also died, the power of Gangabai to make the adoption revived and thus the adoption was valid. This argument, in our opinion, is not well founded as it is based on an incorrect apprehension of the true basis of the rule

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's revival argument misapprehends spiritual duty transfer; once passed to grandson, grandmother's power gone permanently

holdings.text: where the duty of providing for the continuance of the line for spiritual purposes which was upon the father, and was laid by him conditionally upon the mother, has been assumed by the son and by him passed on to a grandson or to the sons widow, the mothers power is gone

anchor.surface_text: It being clear upon the decisions above referred to that the interposition of a grandson, or the sons widow, brings the mothers power of adoption to an end, but that the mere birth of a son does not do so, and that this is not based upon a question of vesting or divesting of property, their Lordships think that the true reason must be that where the duty of providing for the continuance of the line for spiritual purposes

holdings.reasoning_summary: True basis from Amarendra: permanent transfer of spiritual continuance duty extinguishes prior power

holdings.text: the ratio of the decision in Bapuji v. Gangaram was erroneous

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment there is not only an obvious fallacy in this reasoning but it is based on a wrong apprehension of the true reasons stated for the rule in Amarendras case... We are therefore clearly of opinion that the ratio of the decision in Bapuji v. Gangaram was erroneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fallacious logic on revival post-remarriage; duty end cannot revive

precedents.citation: Bhoobun Moyee v. Ram Kishore 1 1965 10 M.I.A. 279

anchor.surface_text: Bhoobun Moyee v. Ram Kishore 1  was delivered by Lord Kingsdown. What happened there was that one Gour Kishore died leaving a son Bhowanee and a widow, Chundrabullee, to whom he gave authority to adopt in the event of his sons death.

precedents.cited_proposition: Widow's power of adoption is incapable of execution after the son marries and leaves a widow as heir
precedents.cited_holding: at the time when Chundrabullee professed to exercise her power of adoption, the power was incapable of execution on the ground that Bhowanee had married and left a widow as his heir

precedents.citation: Padma Coomari v. Court of Wards 1 1881 L.R. 8 I.A, 229

anchor.surface_text: This was the decision in Padma Coomari v. Court of Wards 1  wherein a second effort to maintain the validity of his adoption by Chundrabullee was made but without success.

precedents.case_name: Padma Coomari v Court of Wards
precedents.cited_proposition: Upon vesting of estate in widow of son, power of adoption ends and is incapable of execution
precedents.cited_holding: upon the vesting of the estate in the widow of Bhowanee, the power of adoption of Chudrabullee was at an end and incapable of execution
